doughnut.name: Doughnut, glazed, yeast-raised
doughnut.insight: Breakfast trap—269 calories with 13g sugar and trans fats. Spikes blood sugar then crashes. Pure empty calories.

balanced.insight: Refined flour, sugar, and fried oil create nutritional disaster. Minimal vitamins/minerals with 269 empty calories.
pros: Some enriched B vitamins from flour

heart_health.insight: Trans fats damage arteries, saturated fat raises LDL, high sugar increases triglycerides. Terrible for cardiovascular health.

muscle_building.insight: Minimal protein (3.8g) with excess sugar and inflammatory fats. Won't build muscle—just add fat.
cons: Sugar causes insulin spike without muscle benefit

energy.insight: Sugar rush for 20 minutes, then severe crash. GI=76, GL=23 causes blood sugar rollercoaster and fatigue.
pros: Brief sugar spike gives temporary energy

weight_management.insight: 269 calories that don't satiate—just trigger more cravings. One daily doughnut = 28 lbs/year weight gain.

brain_focus.insight: Sugar spike impairs focus after initial 15-minute boost. Trans fats linked to cognitive decline and dementia.
pros: Very brief mental boost from sugar

gut_health.insight: Almost no fiber (0.9g), high sugar feeds harmful bacteria, refined flour disrupts microbiome. Gut disaster.

blood_sugar.insight: One of worst foods for blood sugar—GI=76, GL=23. Causes massive spike then crash. Promotes insulin resistance.

bone_joint.insight: Minimal calcium (26mg). Inflammatory oils and AGEs from frying worsen joint pain. Sugar promotes inflammation.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Highly inflammatory—trans fats, oxidized oils, sugar, and AGEs from frying. One of worst foods for inflammation.

sugar.tip: Absorbed immediately—causes rapid blood sugar spike

avoidWith.reason: No nutritional value—skip entirely or save for rare indulgence

tips.prepTip: Better option: whole grain toast with nut butter and banana

commonMistakes: Thinking 'just one won't hurt' (sets up sugar cravings all day)
Eating on empty stomach (massive blood sugar swing)
Pairing with coffee (creates insulin spike + cortisol surge)
doughnut.pregnancyNotes: Safe occasionally but offers no nutritional value. Choose nutrient-dense foods for fetal development.

pediatric.ageAppropriate: Avoid for young children; rare treat only for older kids

pie.name: Pie, fruit, two crust
pie.insight: 290 calories per slice with 18g sugar. Refined crust and excess sugar outweigh minimal fruit benefits. Occasional dessert only.

balanced.insight: Refined flour crust and sugar dominate any fruit benefits. 290 calories with minimal nutrients except simple carbs and fat.

heart_health.insight: High sugar increases triglycerides, saturated fat raises LDL, high sodium raises blood pressure. Bad for heart.

muscle_building.insight: Minimal protein (2.4g) with excess sugar and fat. Won't support muscle growth—just stores as fat.

energy.insight: High GI (69) and GL (30) cause rapid blood sugar spike then crash. Brief energy followed by fatigue.
pros: Quick energy from sugar and carbs

weight_management.insight: 290 calories with low satiety—easy to eat multiple slices. Sugar and fat combination promotes weight gain.

brain_focus.insight: Sugar spike impairs focus after initial boost. High glycemic load causes brain fog and mood swings.

gut_health.insight: Low fiber (1.6g), high sugar feeds harmful bacteria, refined flour has no prebiotics. Disrupts gut microbiome.

blood_sugar.insight: Massive glycemic load (30)—one of worst desserts for blood sugar. Refined crust + sugar creates severe spike.

bone_joint.insight: Minimal calcium (11mg). Sugar promotes inflammation, worsening joint pain. No bone-building nutrients.

anti_inflammatory.insight: High sugar is powerfully inflammatory. Refined flour and omega-6 oils worsen inflammation. Avoid if joint/autoimmune issues.

sugar.tip: Absorbed rapidly despite fat content—still spikes blood sugar

avoidWith.reason: Dessert only, not a food group

tips.storage: Refrigerate within 2 hours; consume within 3-4 days
tips.cooking: If making at home: use whole wheat crust and reduce sugar by 1/3
tips.prepTip: Better option: baked apple with cinnamon and Greek yogurt

commonMistakes: Eating large slice (doubles calories to 580)
Adding ice cream (adds 200+ more calories)
Thinking fruit filling makes it healthy (sugar cancels benefits)
pie.pregnancyNotes: Safe occasionally if fully baked. Offers minimal nutrition—choose nutrient-dense desserts instead.

apple_pie.name: Pie, apple, two crust
apple_pie.insight: Classic American dessert—296 calories with 19.5g sugar per slice. Refined crust negates apple benefits. Occasional treat only.

balanced.insight: Refined flour, butter/shortening, and 19.5g sugar overwhelm any apple nutrition. 296 empty calories.
pros: Apples provide some fiber and vitamin C

heart_health.insight: High sugar raises triglycerides, saturated fat raises LDL, sodium increases blood pressure. Terrible for heart health.

muscle_building.insight: Minimal protein (2.4g) with excess sugar and saturated fat. Zero muscle-building benefit—just stores as body fat.

energy.insight: High glycemic load (30) causes rapid spike then severe crash. Brief energy followed by fatigue and hunger.

weight_management.insight: 296 calories with minimal satiety. Sugar-fat combination maximally promotes fat storage. Eat = gain weight.

brain_focus.insight: Sugar spike impairs focus after 20-minute boost. Blood sugar crash causes brain fog, irritability, poor concentration.
cons: Sugar crash causes severe brain fog

gut_health.insight: Low fiber (1.6g), high sugar feeds harmful bacteria, refined flour has zero prebiotics. Disrupts microbiome balance.
pros: Apples provide minimal fiber (cooked breaks down)

blood_sugar.insight: One of worst desserts for blood sugar—GL=30, GI=69. Refined crust + 19.5g sugar creates massive spike and crash.

bone_joint.insight: Minimal calcium (11mg), no vitamin D. Sugar promotes inflammation, worsening arthritis and joint pain.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Despite quercetin in apples, high sugar, refined flour, and saturated fat create net inflammatory effect. Avoid if inflammation issues.
pros: Apples have quercetin (mostly destroyed in processing)

quercetin.tip: Most quercetin destroyed during baking—fresh apples far better

pairWith.reason: Traditional dessert—save for Thanksgiving, special occasions

avoidWith.reason: Adding ice cream doubles calories and sugar

tips.storage: Refrigerate within 2 hours; consume within 3-4 days or freeze up to 4 months
tips.cooking: If making at home: use whole wheat crust, reduce sugar by half, add oats to filling
tips.prepTip: Better option: baked apple with cinnamon, no crust, topped with Greek yogurt

commonMistakes: Thinking apples make it healthy (sugar and crust cancel benefits)
Eating à la mode (adds 200+ calories from ice cream)
Cutting large slices (300+ calories becomes 500+)
apple_pie.pregnancyNotes: Safe occasionally if fully baked. Offers minimal nutrition for fetal development—choose nutrient-dense foods.

sugar.name: Sugar, granulated white
sugar.insight: Pure empty calories—100% sucrose with zero nutrients. Highly addictive, inflammatory, and linked to every chronic disease. Minimize ruthlessly.

balanced.insight: Absolute zero nutritional value—pure refined sucrose. No vitamins, minerals, protein, fat, or fiber. Literal empty calories.

heart_health.insight: Raises triglycerides, promotes LDL oxidation, increases blood pressure, causes insulin resistance. Directly damages cardiovascular system.

muscle_building.insight: Zero protein, zero nutrients. Insulin spike without muscle-building support. Only use: post-workout with protein (but better options exist).
pros: Insulin spike post-workout can help nutrient delivery IF paired with protein

energy.insight: Immediate 15-20 minute energy spike followed by crash. Creates blood sugar rollercoaster and fatigue. Not sustainable energy.
pros: Instant blood sugar spike gives brief energy

weight_management.insight: Empty calories that trigger cravings and don't satisfy. Directly promotes fat storage and obesity. Primary driver of weight gain.

brain_focus.insight: Blood sugar spike impairs focus, causes brain fog, mood swings, anxiety. Highly addictive—hijacks dopamine pathways like drugs.

gut_health.insight: Feeds harmful bacteria, disrupts microbiome balance, increases intestinal permeability. Destroys gut health systematically.

blood_sugar.insight: Pure glucose spike—among worst substances for blood sugar control. Causes insulin resistance and diabetes with regular intake.

bone_joint.insight: Leeches calcium from bones to buffer acidity. Promotes inflammation worsening arthritis. Zero bone-building nutrients.

anti_inflammatory.insight: One of most inflammatory substances you can consume. Raises all inflammatory markers, forms AGEs, promotes chronic disease.

sucrose.tip: Absorbed within minutes—immediate blood sugar spike

avoidWith.reason: Add zero nutritional value—minimize or eliminate entirely

tips.storage: Airtight container in cool, dry place
tips.cooking: Reduce by 1/3 in most recipes without noticing
tips.prepTip: Better options: stevia, monk fruit, or just reduce sweetness tolerance

commonMistakes: Adding to coffee/tea (multiple times daily adds up to 200+ calories)
Thinking 'natural sugar' is different (table sugar IS from sugarcane/beets)
Not reading labels (hidden in 74% of packaged foods)

cautions.heart_disease: Limit to <25g/day for women, <36g/day for men (AHA)

sugar.pregnancyNotes: Safe in very small amounts but offers zero nutrition. Choose nutrient-dense foods for fetal development.
drugInteractions: May interfere with diabetes medications (causes blood sugar spikes)

pediatric.ageAppropriate: <2 years: ZERO added sugar (AAP); 2+ years: <25g/day total

white_sugar.name: Sugar, granulated white
white_sugar.insight: 1 tablespoon = 49 empty calories and 13g sugar (half your daily limit). Addictive, inflammatory, disease-promoting. Avoid.

balanced.insight: Absolute nutritional void—pure refined sucrose with zero vitamins, minerals, fiber, or protein. Literal definition of empty calories.

heart_health.insight: Dramatically raises triglycerides, oxidizes LDL, increases blood pressure. 1 tbsp daily increases heart disease risk significantly.

muscle_building.insight: Zero protein, zero building blocks. Insulin spike without muscle support. Only debatable use: post-workout with protein shake (better options exist).
pros: Post-workout insulin spike MAY help if paired with protein (not recommended)

energy.insight: Massive blood sugar spike for 15-20 minutes, then severe crash and fatigue. Creates energy rollercoaster and dependency.
pros: Instant blood sugar spike = brief energy

weight_management.insight: 49 calories that provide zero satiety and trigger intense cravings. Directly promotes fat storage, especially visceral belly fat.

brain_focus.insight: Brief mental boost followed by brain fog, poor focus, mood swings. Highly addictive—activates same brain regions as cocaine.

gut_health.insight: Feeds Candida and pathogenic bacteria, starves beneficial bacteria, increases gut permeability. Systematically destroys microbiome.

blood_sugar.insight: Pure glucose bomb. 1 tablespoon causes significant blood sugar spike. Regular intake leads directly to insulin resistance and diabetes.

bone_joint.insight: Leeches calcium from bones to neutralize acidity. Highly inflammatory for joints. Zero bone-supporting nutrients.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Extremely pro-inflammatory. Raises all inflammatory markers, forms AGEs, promotes oxidative stress. Linked to all chronic diseases.

sucrose.tip: Absorbed within minutes—immediate blood sugar spike

avoidWith.reason: Provides zero nutrition—eliminate or minimize drastically

tips.storage: Airtight container in cool, dry place
tips.cooking: Cut sugar by 1/3 to 1/2 in recipes—you won't miss it
tips.prepTip: Retrain taste buds by eliminating gradually—takes 2-3 weeks

commonMistakes: Adding to coffee/beverages multiple times daily (adds 200+ calories)
Thinking 'organic sugar' is healthier (chemically identical)
Not tracking—1 can soda = 3 tablespoons (39g)
Ignoring hidden sugar in packaged foods

cautions.diabetes: Absolutely avoid—causes severe blood sugar spikes
cautions.obesity: Primary contributor—American Heart Association recommends <25g/day women, <36g/day men
cautions.fatty_liver: Excess sugar converted to liver fat

white_sugar.pregnancyNotes: Safe in minimal amounts but zero nutrition. Excess linked to gestational diabetes. Choose nutrient-dense foods.

pediatric.ageAppropriate: <2 years: ZERO added sugar (AAP recommendation); 2-18 years: <25g/day maximum

candy_bar.name: Candy bar, milk chocolate with almonds
candy_bar.insight: 216 calories with 19g sugar. Almonds and magnesium (46mg) provide minor benefits—massively outweighed by sugar and saturated fat. Rare treat only.

balanced.insight: Almonds provide magnesium (46mg), calcium, and fiber, but 19g sugar and ultra-processed ingredients dominate. Net negative.

heart_health.insight: Almonds provide healthy fats and magnesium, but high sugar raises triglycerides and saturated fat raises LDL. Net negative for heart.

muscle_building.insight: Minimal protein (3.7g) with excess sugar. Magnesium supports muscle function but not a muscle-building food.

energy.insight: Sugar provides quick energy spike but crash follows. Fat and fiber from almonds provide some sustained energy. Medium GI=55.

weight_management.insight: 216 calories in tiny bar with moderate satiety. Sugar-fat combination promotes fat storage. Easy to eat multiple bars.
pros: Some satiety from almonds and fiber

brain_focus.insight: Magnesium and minimal caffeine (8mg) support brain function, but sugar spike then crash impairs focus overall.

gut_health.insight: 2g fiber from almonds helps slightly, but high sugar feeds harmful bacteria. Ultra-processed ingredients disrupt microbiome.
pros: Some cocoa polyphenols (minimal in milk chocolate)

blood_sugar.insight: Medium GI (55), medium GL (12). Fat and fiber slow absorption slightly, but 19g sugar still spikes blood sugar significantly.
pros: Fat and fiber slow sugar absorption

bone_joint.insight: Good calcium (75mg, 8% DV) and magnesium (46mg) from almonds and milk. But sugar is inflammatory for joints.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Almonds and cocoa have antioxidants (ORAC 2840), but high sugar is pro-inflammatory. Net effect slightly inflammatory.
pros: Some cocoa flavanols (low in milk chocolate)

flavanols.tip: Milk chocolate has minimal flavanols—dark chocolate far better

avoidWith.reason: Occasional treat only—not a snack food

tips.storage: Cool, dry place (NOT fridge—causes bloom); 60-70°F ideal
tips.prepTip: Better option: 1oz dark chocolate (70%+) with handful of raw almonds separately

commonMistakes: Eating king-size bar (doubles calories to 432)
Thinking almonds make it healthy (sugar cancels benefits)
Using as meal replacement (no complete nutrition)
Eating when stressed (sugar worsens mood swings)
candy_bar.pregnancyNotes: Safe occasionally but choose nutrient-dense snacks for fetal development. High sugar not ideal during pregnancy.

pediatric.ageAppropriate: 2+ years as rare treat; avoid regular consumption
pediatric.chokingRisk: moderate (whole almonds can be choking hazard <4 years)
